key_findings: N² package provides a unified Python framework for nearest neighbor-based matrix completion methods, consolidating multiple NN approaches through a modular, extensible interface that enables rapid experimentation and benchmarking across diverse applications.

Nearest neighbor methods have re-emerged as competitive alternatives to traditional matrix completion approaches, offering strong empirical performance with theoretical guarantees including entry-wise error bounds, confidence intervals, and minimax optimality properties.

The framework introduces a new NN variant that achieves state-of-the-art results in several experimental settings, demonstrating the practical value of the unified approach for method development and comparison.

N² supports both researchers and practitioners with a comprehensive benchmark suite including real-world datasets from healthcare (HeartSteps V1), recommender systems (MovieLens), causal inference (Proposition 99), and LLM evaluation (PromptEval), moving beyond synthetic scenarios.

The modular design enables easy integration of new NN-based methods and supports cross-validation functionality, making it suitable for production deployment and academic research with robust evaluation capabilities.
limitations: Limited information provided about computational complexity and scalability constraints for large-scale matrix completion tasks
Specific performance metrics and quantitative comparisons with existing methods are not detailed in the available content
future_work: Extension of the framework to support additional NN variants and integration with other matrix completion paradigms

resource_requirements.data_requirements: Supports diverse datasets from healthcare, recommender systems, and evaluation benchmarks

problem_addressed: Fragmented landscape of nearest neighbor-based matrix completion methods lacking unified implementation and benchmarking framework
